titleInfo.title: McKinley High School Oral History Project: Old South Baton Rouge Social Organizations
titleInfo.subTitle: Bernestine B. McGee oral history interview, 2002

name.description: Bernestine McGee was born in Gilbert, Louisiana. She received her B.S. degree from Southern University, and her master's and doctorate degrees from the University of Iowa. McGee is an administrator and professor of nutrition at Southern University in Baton Rouge. She is the president of the Mu Zeta chapter of Zeta Phi Beta sorority.

subject.topic: Zeta Phi Beta Sorority.--Mu Zeta Chapter (Baton Rouge, La.)
African American Greek letter societies--Louisiana--Baton Rouge.
Women volunteers in social service--Louisiana--Baton Rouge.

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)
mods.accessCondition: Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright is retained by Louisiana State University in accordance with U.S. copyright laws.

"E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments. See instructions for ordering reprints of this audio here: http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/services/duplication.html Mention the ""Item number"" or ""Item URL"" in your request. "
mods.abstract: McGee discusses the aims, ideals and history of Zeta Phi Beta sorority, particularly the Mu Zeta chapter, founded in Baton Rouge in 1920. She describes chapter activities, which revolve around Zeta Phi Beta's seven point plan of action, and especially focuses on the sorority's work with youth in the community.
